P.HI: Quod non Dant proceres, Dabit Histri.

DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed by Robert Raorth, for Nicholas Vavasour; and are to bee sold at his Shop in the Inner Temple, neere the Church-doore. 1636.

LG.L: THus from the Poet, I am bid to say;
Hee knows what Iudges sit to Doome each Play,
(The Over-curious Critick, or the Wise)
The one with squint; 'Tother with Sunn-like eyes,
Shootes through each scaene; The one cries all things down
Tother, hides strangers Faults, close as his Owne:
Las! Those that out of custome come to jeere,
(Sung the full quire of the Nine Muses heere)
So Carping,—not from Wit, but Apish spite,
And Fether'd Ignorance,—Thus! ô Poet does slight.
'Tis not a gay sute, or Distorted Face,
Can beate his Merit off,—Which has won Grace
In the full Theater;—Nor can now feare
The Teeth of any Snaky whisperer;
But to the white, and sweete unclowded Brow,
(The heaven where true worth moves) our Po do's bow:
Patrons of Arts, and Pilots to the Stage,
Who guide it (through all Tempests) from the Rage
Of envious Whirlewindes,—ô, doe you but steere
His Muse, This day; And bring her toth' wished shore,
You are those Delphick Powers whom shee'le adore.

LIST.ITEM: Tibaldo Neri, Lover of Dariene L. Vanni's wife.

DIV1.HEAD: THE VVONDER OF A Kingdome.
Actus primus. Scaena prima.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Duke of Florence, Prince of Pisae, Nicoletto Van∣ni, Trebatio his sonne, Mutio, Philippo, Tornelli, Gallants, Tibaeldo Neri, Alphonsina his sister, Daerie∣ne Old Vannies wife, Cargo a serving-man.

SP.L: WEe surfit heere on Pleasures: Seas nor Land
Cannot invite us to a Feast more glorious,
Then this day we have sat at: my Lord Vanni,
You have an excellent seate heere; Tis a building
May entertaine a Caesar: but you and I
Should rather talke of Tombs, then Pallaces,
Let's leave all to our hoires, for we are old.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: Old! hem? all heart of brasse, sound as a bell,
Old? why, Ile tell your Graces; I have gone
But halfe the bridge ore yet; there lies before me
As much as I have pass'd, and I'le goe it all.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Mad Vanni still.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Old Oakes doe not easily fall:
Decembers cold hand combes my head and beard,
But May swimmes in my blood; and he that walkes
Without his wooden third legge, is never old.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: What is your age my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Age, what call you age?
I have liv'd some halfe a day, some halfe an houre.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: A tree of threescore-yeares growth; nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: A meere slip, you have kept good diet my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Let whores kepe diet,
Tibaldo ner'e; never did Rivers runn
In wilder, madder streames, then I have done,
I'le drinke as hard yet as an Englishman,

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: And they are now best Drinkers.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: They put downe the Dutch-men cleane,

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Ile yet upon a wager hit any fencers button,

SP.SPEAKER: Car,
SP.L: Some of 'em ha' no buttons to their doublets.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Then knave Ile hit his flesh, and hit your cocks-
If you crosse mine once more. (combe

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Nay be not angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: I have my Passees: and my Passadoes,
My Longes, my Stockadoes, Imbrocadoes,
And all my Pimtoes, and Pimtillioes
Here at my fingers ends.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: By my faith 'tis well.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Old why; I ne're tooke Phisicke, nor ever will,
I'le trust none that has Art and leave to kill:
Now for that chopping herbe of hell Tobacco;
The idle-mans-Devill, and the Drunkards-whore,
I never medled with her, my smoake goes,
Out at my kitchin chimney, not my nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: And some Lords have no chimnies but their noses.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Tobacco-shopps shew like prisons in hell;
Hote, smoaky, stinking, and I hate the smell.

SP.SPEAKER: Pis.
SP.L: Who'd thinke that in a coale of Ashy white,
Such fire were glowing?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: May not a snuffe give light?

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: You see it doe's in him.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: A withered-tree, doth oft beare branches.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: What thinke you then of me sweere Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: Troth my Lord as of a horse, vilely, if he can
Neither wihi, nor wagg's-Taile.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: The Lady Alphonsina Neri, has given it you my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: The time may come I may give it her too.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo,
SP.L: I doubt Lord Vanni she will cracke no Nutts,
With such a tough shell, as is yours and mine,
But leaving this, lets see you pray, at Court,

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: I thanke your grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Your wife, and your faire daughter,
One of the stars of Florence with your sonne
Heire to your worth and Honours, Trebatio Vanni.

SP.SPEAKER: Treb.
SP.L: I shall attend your grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: The holy knot,
Hymea shall shortly tie, and in faire bands,
Vnite Florence and Pisa by the hands,
Or Fyametta and this Pisa Duke
(Our Noble-son in law) and at this daie,
Pray be not absent.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: We shall your will obey,

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: We heare there is a gallant that out-vies
Vs, and our court for brauery, and expence,
For royall feasts, trium hs and revellings.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: He's my neere kinsman, mine owne brothers son,
Who desperately a prodigall race doth ronne,
And for this riotous humour, he has the by-name,
Signior Torrenti, a swift Head-long streame.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: But ther's another layes on more then he.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Old Iacomo? open handed charitie,
Sit's ever at his gates to welcome guests,
He makes no bone-fires, as my riotous kinsman,
And yet his chimneis cast out braver smoake,
The Bellows which he blowes with are good deeds,
The rich he smiles upon, the poore he feeds.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: These gallants we'le be feasted by, and Feast
Fames praises of 'em, shall make us their guest,
Meane time we'le hence

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I have News to tell your Lordship, Signior Angelo (of the Locti Famely is banished.

SP.SPEAKER: Dari.
SP.L: How banish't? alas poore Angelo Lotti.

SP.SPEAKER: Treb.
SP.L: Why must he goe from Florence?

SP.SPEAKER: Cargo.
SP.L: Because he can stay there no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: To what end is he driven from the Citie?

SP.SPEAKER: Cargo.
SP.L: To the end he should goe into some other my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Hoida.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: I hope this is newes Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: What speake the people of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: As bells ring; some out, some in, all jangle, they say he Has dealt with the Genoway against the state: but whether with the men, or the women; tis to be stood upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Away Sir knave and foole.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Sir knave, a new word: fooles, and knaves Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: This muttering long agoe flew to mine eare,
The Genoway is but a line throwne out,
But Fiametta's love, the net that choakes him.

SP.SPEAKER: Tre.
SP.L: He's worthy of her equall,

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Peace foolish boy,
At these state bone-fires (whose flames reach so high)
To stand aloose, is safer then too nigh.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Why brother, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: I'me ill, exceeding ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: That's not well.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Sure I did surfet at Lord Vannies.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Surfet? you eate some Meate against your stomack.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.P: No, but I had a stomack to one dish, and the not tasting it, makes me sick at heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Was it fish or flesh?

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Flesh sure, if I hit the marke right.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: I'st not the missing of a marke (which you long to hit)
Makes you draw sighes in stead of arrowes?

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Would I had beene a thousand leagues from thence,
When I sat downe at's table or bin partner
With Angelo Lotti in his banishment;
Oh! sister Alphonsina, there I dranke
My bae the strongest poison that e're man
Drew from a Ladies eye, now swelling in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: By casting of thy water thy, I guesse thou would'st
Have a medcine for the greene sicknes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: 'Tis a greene wound indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Tent it, tent it, and keepe it from ranckling, you are
Over head and eares in love.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: I am and with such mortall Arrowes pierc't
I shall fall downe—

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: There's no hurt in that.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: And dye unlesse he her pitty
Send me a quicke and sweete recovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: And faith what doctresse is she must call you patient?

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Faire Dariene, the Lord Vannies wife—

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: How! Dariene? can no feather fit you but the broach in an
Old mans hatt? were there so many dainty dishes
To fill your belly, and must you needs long for that dish
The master of the house setts up for his owne tooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Could love be like a subject, tied to lawes,
Then might you speake this language.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Love? a disease as common with young-gallants as
Swaggering and drinking Tobacco, there's not one
Of 'um all but will to day ly drawing on for a
Woman, as if they were puffing and blowing at a streight boot,
And to morrow be ready to knock at deathes doore,
But I wo'd faine see one of you enter and set in
His staffe.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: You shall see me then do so.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: I shall looke so old first, I shall be taken for thy gran∣dame; come, come 'tis but a worme betweene the skinne And the flesh, and to be taken out with the point of a Waiting-womans needle, as well as a great Countesses.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: If this be all the comfort you will lend me,
Would you might leave me—

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: Leave thee in sicknes? I had more need give thee a Caudle; and thrust thy adle-head into a night-Capp, for looke you brother—

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Even what you will must out

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: If what you will might so too, then would you be in
Tune: I warrant, if the sucket stood here before
Thee, thy stomach would goe against it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Yes sure my stomack would goe against it:
'Tis onely that which breeds in me despaire.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Despaire for a woman? they hang about mens
Neckes in some places thicker then hope upon poles.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Her walls of chastitie cannot be beaten downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Walls of chastitie? walls of wafer-cakes, I have
Knowne a woman carry a fether-bed, and a man in't
In her minde, when in the streete she cast up the white of
Her eye like a Puritane.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Sister you do but stretch me on the racke
And with a laughing cheeke increase my paine,
Be rather pitifull and ease my torments
By teaching me how in this dreadfull storme,
I may escape ship-wrack and attaine that shore
Where I may live, heere else I'me sure to die.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Well brother, since you will need s saile by such a
Starre as I shall point out, looke you heere it is; if she were
Your Fether-makers, Taylors or Barbers wife,
Baite a hooke with gold, and with it—

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: I doe conjure you by that noble blood
Which makes me call you sister, cease to powre
Poison into a wound, so neere my heart,
And if to cure Loves-paines there be an Art.
Woman me thinkes should know it cause she breeds it,

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: That cunning woman you take me to be, and because
I see you dissemble not, heer's my medcine.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: I shall for ever thanke you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: First send for your Barber.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: For heavens sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Your barber shall not come to rob you of your beard,
I'le deale in no concealements—

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Oh! fie, fie, fie—

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: But let him by rubbing of you quicken
Your spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: So so.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Then whistle your gold-finches (your gallants) to your fist.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Y'ar mad, y'ar mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: Into a Tanerne, Drinke stiffe, sweare stiffe; have your musicke, and your brace, dance, and whiffe Tobacco,
SP.L: Till all smoake Agen, and split Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: You split my very heart in pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: And doe thus, but till the Moore cutts off her hornes; Laugh in the day, and sleepe in the night: and this wenching fier will be burnt out of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Away, away, cruell you are to kill,
When to give life, you have both power and skill.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Alas, poore brother now I pitty thee and wo'd doe
Any thing to helpe thee to thy longing, but that a
Gap must be broken, in another mans hedge to rob
His orchard, within there Luca Angelo, give him
Musick:
Musicke has helpt some mad-men, let it then
Charme him, Love makes fooles of the wisest men.
SP.STAGE: Enter at one doore, Angelo Lotti, and Baptista, at the other, Piero, and Iaspero.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Yonders that villaine, keepe off Iaspero:
This prey I'le cease.

SP.SPEAKER: Iasp.
SP.L: Be more advised Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bap.
SP.L: At whose life shoote you?

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: At that slaves there.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Slave? I know you for the Dukes sonne, but I know noc ause of quarrell, or this base reproach.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Thou art a villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Wherein?

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: And by witch-craft,
Had stole my sister Fiamettas heart,
Forceing her leave a Prince his bed for thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: If for her love you come to kill me; heere
SP.P: I'le point you to a doore where you may enter and fetch out a loath'd life.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Iaspero.

SP.SPEAKER: Iasp.
SP.L: Oh my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Let him come, I ow her all;
And that debt will I pay her gladly.

SP.SPEAKER: Iasp.
SP.L: Deare Sir heare him—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: But if on any other fier of rage;
You thirst to drinke my blood, heere I defie
You, and your malice; and returne the villaine
Into your throate.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: So brave sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: I charge you in the Dukes name, keepe the peace;
Beate downe their weapons, knock em downe Cargo.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: I have a Iustices warrant to apprehend your weapons,
Therefore I charge you deliver.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: Oh my Lord: make a fray in an open streete? 'tis to
Make a bon-fire to draw children and fooles
Together; Signior Angelo, pray be wise, and begon.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: I doe but guard my life (my Lord) from danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: Sir, you doe exercise your violence;
Vpon a man, stab'd to the heart with wounds;
You see him sinking, and you set your foote
Vpon his head, to kill him with two deathes;
Trample not thus on a poore banish'd man.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: If hee be banish'd, why dwells hee ith'house, whose
Tiles are pull'd downe over his head? You must hunt
No more in this Parke of Florence; why then
Doe you lie sneaking heere, to steale venison?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: My Lords, I take my last leave of you all;
Of love, and fortunes—

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: Lower thou canst not fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Iasp.
SP.L: Trust mee, my Lord, This Lotti is a man,
(Setting aside his rivall-ship in love,
For which you hate him) so abundant rich
In all the Vertues of a Gentle-man,
That had you read their file, as I haue done,
You would not onely fall in love with him,
And hold him worthy of a Princesse bed,
But grieve, that for a woman, such a man
Should so much suffer; in being so put downe,
Never to rise againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Nicol.
SP.L: A terrible case, i'de not be in't for all Florence.

SP.SPEAKER: Pie.
SP.L: Troth deare friend,
The praises which have crown'd him with thy Iudgement,
Make mee to cast on him an open eye,
Which was before shut, and I pittie him.
I Never heard 'mongst all your Romane spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Iasp.
SP.L: That any held so bravely up his head,
In such a sea of troubles (that come rowling
One on anothers necke) as Lotti doth,
Hee puts the spite of Fortune to disgrace,
And makes her, when shee frownes worst, turne her face.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: No more: I love him; and for all the Dukedome,
Would not have cut so Noble a spreading Vine,
To draw from it one drop of blood; Lord Vanni,
I thanke you that you cur'd our wounded peace,
So fare you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: A good health to you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Iasp.
SP.L: You play the Constable wisely.

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: And I his Beadle, I hope as wisely.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: The Constable wisely; Cargo he calls me foole by craft,
But let 'em passe.

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: As Gentle-men doe by Creditors (muffled)

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.P: I haue another case to handle: thou know'st the Donna Alphonsina, of the Neri Familie.

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: The little Paraquinto that was heere when the Duke
Was feasted, shee had quick-silver in her mouth, for
Her tongue, like a Bride the first night, never lay still.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: The same Aspen-leafe, the same; is't not a Galley for
The Great Turke to be row'd in?

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: I thinke my Lord, in calme weather, shee may set upon
A Gally-ass bigge as your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: Commend me to this Angelica.

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: Angelica-water is good for a cold stomach.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: I am all fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: Shee's a cooler.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: Would 'twere come to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: A small thing does it my Lord; in the time a
Flemming drinkes a Flap-dragon.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.P: Give her this paper, and this; in the one she may know my minde, in the other, feele me: this a Letter, this a Iewell:
SP.L: Tell her, I kisse the little white naile of her little white
Finger, of her more little white hand, of her most
Little white bodie.

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: Her tell-tale, for all this will I bee.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.P: Thou hast beene my weavers shuttle to runne betwixt me and my stuffes of Procreandi causa.

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: A suite of Stand-farther-off, had bin better sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: No Cargo, I have still the Lapis mirabilis; be thou close—

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: As my Ladies Chamber-maide.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: Away then, nay quicke knave, thou rack'st mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: I goe to stretch you to your full length.
SP.STAGE: Enter Iocomo Gentili, in a suite of gray, Velvet-gowne, Cap, Chaine, Steward, and Serving-men, Mutio, Philippo, Tornelli Montinello.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Happy be your arivall, Noble friends;
You are the first, that like to Doves repaire
To my new building; you are my first-borne guests,
My eldest sonnes of hospitalitie;
Here's to my hearty wellcomes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mutio.
SP.L: Worthy Lord,
In one word, and the word of one, for all,
Our thankes are as your welcomes, Infinite.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Rome in her Auncient pride, never rais'd up
A worke of greater wonder, then this building.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Tis finish'd, and the cost stands on no score,
None can for want of payment, at my doore,
Curse my foundation, praying the roofe may fall
On the proud builders head, seeing the smoake goe
Out of those Chimneys, for whose bricks I owe.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: To erect a frame so glorious, large, and hie,
Would draw a very sea of silver drie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: My Lord Iocomo Gentili, pray tell us,
How much money have you buried under this kingly building?

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Pray call it not so:
The humble shrub, no Cedar heere shall grow;
You see Three hundred Dorick pillars stand
About one square, Three hundred Noble friends
Lay'd (in their loves) at raising of those Columnes,
A piece of gold under each Pedestall,
With his name grav'd upon the bottome stone,
Except that cost, all other was mine owne;
See heere, each dayes expences are so great,
They make a volume, for in this appeares,
It was no taske of weekes, or moneths, but yeares:
I trust my steward onely with the key,
Which keepes that secret; heere's Arithmetick
For churles to cast up, there's nhe roote of all;
If you have skill in numbers, number that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Good Mr. Steward read it.

SP.SPEAKER: Stew.
SP.L: All the charge
In the grosse summe, amounteth to—

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: To what?
Thou vaine vaine-glorious foole, goe burne that Booke,
No Herald needs to blazon Charities Armes;
Goe burne it presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Stew.
SP.L: Burne it?

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Away,
I lanch not forth a ship, with drums and gunnes,
And Trumpets, to proclaime my gallantry;
He that will reade the wasting of my gold,
Shall find it writ in ashes, which the winde
Will scatter ere he spends it; Another day,
The wheele may turne, and I that built thus high,
May by the stormes of want, be driven to dwell
In a thatch't Cottage; Rancor shall not then
Spit poyson at me, pinning on my backe
This card; Hee that spent thus much, now does lack.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: Why to your house adde you so many gates?

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: My gates fill up the number of seuen dayes,
At which, of guests, seven severall sorts Ile welcome:
On Munday, Knights whose fortunes are sunke low;
On Tuesday, those that all their life-long read
The huge voluminous wonders of the deepe,
Sea-men (I meane) and so on other dayes,
Others shall take their turnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Why have you then built twelue such vaste roomes.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: For the yeares twelve moones;
In each of which, twelue Tables shall be spread;
At them, such whom the world scornes, shall be fed,
The windowes of my building, which each morne,
Are Porters, to let in mans comfort (light)
Are numbred just three hundred sixtie five,
And in so many daies the sunne does drive
His chariot stuck with beames of Burnish't gold,
My Almes shall such diurnall progresse make
As doe's the sunne in his bright-Zodiack.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: You differ from the guise of other lands,
Where Lords lay all their livings on the racke,
Not spending it in bread, but on the backe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Such Lords eate men, but men shall eate up me,
My uncle the Lord Abbot had a soule
Subtile and quick, and searching as the fier,
By Magicke-stayers he went as deepe as hell,
And if in devills possession gold be kept,
He brought some sure from thence, 'tis hid in caves
Knowne (save to me) to none, and like a spring
The more 'tis drawne, the more it still doth rise,
The more my heape wastes, more it multiplies.
Now whither (as most rich-men doe) he pawn'd
His soule for that deare purchase none can tell,
But by his bed-side when he saw death stand
Fetching a deepe groane, me he catch't-by'th hand
Cal'd me his heire, and charg'd me well to spend
What he had got ill, deale (quoth he) a doale
which round (with good mens prayers) may guard my soule
Now at her setting forth: let none feele want
That knock but at thy gates: do wrong to none,
And what request to thee so ear is made,
If honest, see it never be denay'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: And yow'le performe all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Faire & upright,
As are the strict vowes of an Anchorite:
A benefit given by a Niggards hand
Is and gravily bread, the hunger-sterv'd
Takes it, but cannot eate it; Ile give none such.
Who with free heart shakes out but crums, gives much.

SP.SPEAKER: Mont.
SP.L: In such a ship of worldly cares my Lord
As you must saile now in, yow'le need more Pilots
Then your owne selfe to sit and steare the Helme.
You might doe therefore well to take a wife;

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: A wife? when I shall have one hand in heaven,
To write my happinesse in leaves of starres;
A wife wo'd plucke me by the other downe:
This Barke hath thus long sail'd about the world,
My soule the Pilot, and yet never listen'd
To such a Mare-maids song: a wife, oh fetters,
To mans blest liberty! All this world's a prison,
Heaven the high wall about it, sin the jalour,
But the iron-shackles waying downe our heeles,
Are onely women, those light Angells turne us,
To fleshly devills, I that Sex admire,
But never will sit neere their wanton fier.

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: Who then shall reape the golden corne you sowe?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: 'Tis halfe a curse to them, that build, and spare, and hoard up wealth, yet cannot name an heire.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: My heires shall be poore children fed on almes,
Souldiers that want limbes, schollers poore and scorn'd.
And these will be a sure inheritance;
Not to decay: Mannors and Townes will fall,
Lord-ships and Parkes, Pastures and woods be sold;
But this Land still continues to the Lord:
No subtile trickes of law, can me beguile of this.
But of the beggers-dishe, I shall drinke healthes
To last for ever; whil'st I live, my roofe
Shall cover naked wretches; when I die,
'Tis dedicated to St. Charitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: The Duke inform'd, what trees of goodnesse grow,
Here of your planting, in true loue to your virtues;
Sent us to give you thankes, for crowning Florence,
With fame of such a subject, and entreats you
(Vntill he come himselfe) to accept this token,
Of his faire wishes towards you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Pray returne
my duty to the Duke, tell him I value his love
beyond all jewells in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: H'as vow'd ere long to be your visitant.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: He shall be welcome when he comes, that's all;
Not to a Pallace, but my hospitall.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Wee'le leave your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: My best thoughts goe with you:
My Steward?
SP.STAGE: Enter Steward, and a foolish Gentle-man.

SP.SPEAKER: Stew.
SP.L: Heere my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Is the Booke fired?

SP.SPEAKER: Stew.
SP.L: As you commanded Sir, I saw it burn'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Keep safe that Iewell, and leave me; letters! from whome?

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Signior Ieronimo Guydanes.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Oh sir, I know the businesse: yes, yes, 'tis the same;
Cuidanes lives amongst my bosome friends:
He writes to have me entertaine you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: That's the bough, my bolt flies at, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: What Qualities are you furnish't with?

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: My Education has bin like a Gentle-man.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Have you any skill in song, or Instrument?

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.P: As a Gentleman shoo'd have, I know all, but play on none: I am no Barber.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Barber! no sir, I thinke it; Are you a Linguist?

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: As a Gentleman ought to be, one tongue serues one head;
I am no Pedler, to travell Countries.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: What skill ha'you in horseman-ship?

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: As other Gentlemen have, I ha'rid some beasts in my Time.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Can you write and reade then?

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: As most of your Gentle-men doe, my band has bin
Taken with my marke at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: I see you are a dealer, give me thy hand, Ile entertaine thee howsoeuer, because in thee I keepe halfe a score Gentlemen; thy name.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz
SP.L: A sinius Buzardo——

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: I entertaine thee, good Buzardo.

SP.SPEAKER: Buz.
SP.L: Thankes sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: This fellow's a starke foole, or too wise,
The triall will be with what wing he flies.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus secundus. Scaena prima.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Tibaldo sicke in his chaire, Alphonsina, Mutio, Philippo, Tornelli, Montivello.

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: IN Lawes of courtesie, wee are bound sweete Lady,
(Being thus nigh) to see you and your brother,
Our noble friend, tho' the Duke had not sent.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Thankes worthy sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Signior Tibaldo hath desire to sleepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Then leave him, Companie offends the sicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Our humblest dutie to my Lord the Duke;
If in my Brothers name, and mine, you tender
For this his noble love, wee both shall rest
Highly indebted to you all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: Sweete Madam,
You shall command our lives to worke your good.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Signior, your love.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: All at your service Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: A quick, and good health to your noble Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: And all faire fortunes doubled on your selfe.
SP.P: So: me-thinkes a Lady had more need have a new paire of lips, then a new paire of gloves, for tho' they were both of one skinne, yet one would weare out sooner then the other; I thinke these Courtiers have al offices in the Spicerie, And taking my lips for sweet-meates, are as sawcie with 'em, as if they were Fees; I wonder Tibaldo thou can'st fit still, and not come in for a share; If old Vanni's wife had beene heere, all the parts about you had mov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.P: Thou think'st I lie in, heere's such a gossiping, as if 'twere a Child-bed Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: So 'tis, for Ile sweare, all this stirre is about having a wo∣man brought to bed; marry I doubt it must be a mans lying in.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: I would thy tongue were a man then, to lie.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: I had rather it were a woman, to tell trueth.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Good sister Alphonsina, you still play
The bad Phisicion, I am all on fire,
And you to quench mee, powre on scoopes of oyle;
I feele ten thousand plummets at my heart,
Yet you cry, Lay on more and are more cruell
Then all my tortures.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Sadnesse, I pittie thee,
And will to doe thee service, venture life,
Mine honour being kept spotlesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Gentle sister,
The easiest thing ith' world to begge, I crave,
And the poorest Almes to give.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: But aske and have.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: A friendly counsell, loe that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: 'Tis yours.
Be rul'd by me then; in an ashie sheete,
Cover these glowing embers of defire.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Embers? I wo'd you telt em, 'tis a fire—

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Come, and set hand to paper, Ile indite.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: And shee'le condemne me; no, I will not write.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: Then prethee take this Phisick; be not the sea, to drinke strange Rivers up, yet still be drie; Be like a noble streame, co∣vet to runne betwixt faire bankes, which thou may'st call thine owne, and let those bankes be some faire Ladies armes, fit for thy youth, and birth.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Against your charmes,
Witch, thus I stop mine eares.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Ile hollow them: this Deere runnes in my Lords Parke,
And if you steale it, looke to have Blood-hounds scent you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Are you mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Yes, you shall finde venison-sawce deerer then other flesh.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: No, no, none else must, none shall, none can,
My hunger feede but this; downe will I dive,
And fetch this Pearle, or nere come up alive—

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: Are all my warme cawdles come to this? now I see th'art too farre gone, this Lady hath overspent thee therefore settle thine estate, plucke up a good heart, and Ile pen thy will.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Oh fie, fie.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: Bequeath thy kisses to some Taylor, that hunts out wed∣dings every sunday; Item, Thy sighes to a noyse of fidlers ill paid, thy palenesse to a Fencer fighting at sharpe, thy want of stomack to one of the Dukes guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.P: I begge it at thy hands, that being a woman, thou'It make a wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Hold thy tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: It's an Instrument ever plaid on, cause well strung,
Who's that come into the Chamber there? Oh, Mr. Cargo.

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.P: My Lord hath sent you a Iewell, lock't up in this paper, and the moisture of a goose quill, that's to say, words in that—

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: Oh sir, I thanke your Lord, and this your paines; have him into the Buttery—let me see, Lady, that I love you, I dare sweare like a Lord (I shall have oathes enough then) I send you all that is mine, in hope all shall bee mine that is yours, for it stands to reason, that mine being yours, yours should bee mine, and yours being mine, mine should be yours. Love me, or I die, If I die, you kill me, If you kill me, I will say nothing, but take the blow patiently. I hold my life this Lord has bin bastinado'd, out upon him rammish foxe, he stinks hither; Prethee good Bro∣ther reade.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: Is't Gander moneth with him? How the devill is my may∣denhead blasted? that among such shoales of Gallants, that swim up and downe the Court, no fish bites at the baite of my poore beautie, but this tough Cods-head?

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Oh sister, peace for heavens sake; heere lies health
Even in this bitter pill (for me) so you
Would play but my Phisician, and say, take it;
You are offered heere, to soiourne at his house:
Companion with his Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: Sr, I have you. And I goeing vpon so weightie a busi∣nesse, as getting of children, you would ha' me pin you to my sleeve.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Most true.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: You care not so I turne whore to pleasure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Oh Sister, your high worth is knowne full well
Gainst bse assault, a Fort Impregnable;
And therefore, as you ove my life, ith' sprindge,
Catch this old Wood-cocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: In the flame I'le sindge
My wings, unlesse I put the candle out,
That you i'th'darke may bring your hopes about.
You have wonne me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: You revive me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Have a care you cast not your selfe downe too soone now.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: As for my old Huck-sters artillery, I have walls of
Chastity strong enough shoote he never so hard, to keepe him
From making any breach.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: 'Twill be a noble-battaile on each side;
Yet now my spirits are rouzed, a stratageme
Lies hatching heere, pray helpe me noble sister,
to give it forme and life.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: My best.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: What thinke you?
(The marke of man not yet set in my face)
If as your sister, or your kins-woman,
I goe in womans habit, for thereby,
Speech, free accesse, faire opportunity;
Are had without suspition.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Mine be your will;
Oh me! what paines we take to bring forth ill!
Such a disguise is safe too, since you never but once
Were seene there.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: My wise sister ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Send in the fellow there that brought the letter;
Why how now? doe his leggs faile him already?
A staffe for his declining age.

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: I have a pike-staffe of mine owne already, but I could not
Keep our your scurvy desperate hoggs-head from coming
In upon me, I'me cut i'th'cockscombe.

SP.SPEAKER: Alb.
SP.P: Nothing I see is so like an old-man, as a young∣man drunke.

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: Or when he comes from a wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Before he beare your answer let him sleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Whil'st you laugh at what I could almost weepe.
SP.STAGE: Enter Angelo, like a Doctor, Baptista, his man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Deare friend, I should both wrong my faith & fortunes,
SP.P: To make'em thus dance Antickes; I shall never play the dissembler.

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: Then never play the Lover;
Death! for a woman, I'de be fleade alive,
Could I but finde one constant: i'st such a matter
For you then to put on a Doctours-gowne,
And his flat velvet-Cap, and speake the gibbering
Of an Apothecary.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: If thus disguis'd
I'me taken all the phisicke in the world
Cannot prolong my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: And dying for her,
You venture bravely, all women o're you grave
will pray that they so kinde a man may have,
As to die for'em; say your banishment
Had borne you hence, what hells of discontent,
Had rack'd your soule for her as hers for you?
Should you but faint, well might you seeme untrue,
Where this attempt your loyalty shall approve,
Who ventures farthest winns a Ladies-love.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: How are my beard and haire?

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: Friend I protest,
So rarely counterfeit, as if a painter
Should draw a Doctour: were I sicke my selfe,
And met you with an urinall in my hand,
I'de cast it at your head, unlesse you cast
The water for me, come, all's passing well;
Love which makes pale the cheeks, gives you complexion,
Fit for a sallow French-man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: I will on then,
In France I long haue liv'd, And know the Garbe
Of the French-Mounte-bankes, whose apish gesture,
Although in them I hold ridiculous,
My selfe shall practise.

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: For a Doctours-man,
You see I'me fitted, foote by foote I'le walke,
and meete all dangers sent against your breast.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: I thanke thee noble friend; let's then to court.
The pangs a lover suffers are but short.
SP.STAGE: Enter Florence, Pisa, Nicolletto, Philippo, Tonell, Piero, met by an old Nurse.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: How now Nurse, how does my Fiametta?

SP.SPEAKER: Nurs.
SP.L: Oh my sweete Lord, shees at it agen, at it agen!

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Who are with her? call for more helpe.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurs.
SP.P: More helpe! alas there's my Lady Vanni with her, and Ladies upon Ladies, and Doctours upon Doctours, but all can∣not doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: How does it take her Nurse?

SP.SPEAKER: Nurs.
SP.P: Oh sweete Princesse, it takes her all over with a prick∣ing; first about her stomack, and then she heaves and heaves, that no one man with all his weight, can keepe her downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.P: At this I wonder, that her sicknesse makes her Doctours fooles.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: He that she findes most ease in, is Dr. Iordan.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: I will give halfe my Duke-dome for her health.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Well, well, If death do take her, he shall have the sweet∣est bed-fellow that ever lay by leane mans-side.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: I entreate thee Nurse be tender over her.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurs.
SP.P: Tender quoth a? I'me sure my heeles are growne as hard as hoofes, with trotting for her, I'le put you in one comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: What's that Nurse?

SP.SPEAKER: Nurs.
SP.P: In her greatest conflict sh'as had a worthy feeling of her selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: So, so, I'me glad of it my Lord of Pisa.
Vnder this common blow, which might have strooke the
strongest heart, here pray doe not you shrinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: Sicknes is lifes retainer, Sir, and I
(What is not to be shun'd) beare patiently;
But had she health as sound as hath the spring,
She wo'dto me prove sickly Autumne still.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Oh say not so,

SP.SPEAKER: Pis.
SP.L: I finde it, for being loyall,
As the touch-needle to one starre still turning,
I loose that starre, my faithis paid with scorning.
Who then with eag'es wings of faith and truth,
W'ud in her sun-beames plaie away his youth,
And kisse those flames, which burne but out mine eyes,
With sealding rivers of her cruelties?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: 'Tis but her way-ward sicknes casts this eye of slightnes on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pis.
SP.L: 'Tis my Lord her hate;
For when death sits even almost on her browes,
She spreads her armes abroad, to welcome him,
When in my bridall-bed I finde a grave.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Now Mutio?

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: There's a French-man come to court,
A profest Doctour, that has seen the Princesse,
And will on her recovery pawne his life.

SP.SPEAKER: Flor.
SP.L: Comfort from heaven, I hope, let's see this Doctour.
SP.STAGE: Enter Angelo like a Doctour, Baptista his man.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Welcome good Doctour: have you seen my daughter?
Restore her health, and nothing in my Duke-dome,
Shall be too deare for thee, how doe you Iudge her?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Be me trat me Lord, I finde her a very bad lady, & no well.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Piero take the Duke of Pisa pray and be your sisters visi.

SP.SPEAKER: Piero.
SP.L: Sir we shall, if the Duke please—(tants.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: The poysoned may drinke gall.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Attend the Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Caego.
SP.L: The party Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: Thou shalt have Caesars pay—my Coach,

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: Old Ianuary goes to lie with May.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Doctor I thus have singled you, to sound
The depth of my girles sicknes, that if no skill
Of man can save her, I against heavens will,
May arme my breast with patience, therefore be free.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: By my tra' and fa'my Lor', me no point can play
The hound, and fawne upon de most puissant Roy in de world;
A French-man beare the brave minde for dat.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: So, so, I like him better.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Me gra tanke you, now for de maladie of de Princesse,
Me one two, tre time, feele her pulse, and ron up and downe all
De oder parts of her body, and finde noting but dat
She be trobla with le gran desire of de man.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: A great desire of a man?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: A my trat 'tis verament, she longa to do some ting in Love uponle gentle home.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Doctor thou hit'st her heart, 'tis there shee's wounded,
By a poyson'd Arrow, shot from a villaines hand;
One Angelo of the Lotti Familie,
And till that head be pluckt out, shee will pine,
Vnlesse controul'd by some deepe Art of thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: All tings possibela me fall undergoe, mee ha read Gallen,
SP.P: Hipocratus, Avicen, but no point can peeke out le remedie for de Madam in de bryars of love.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: No medicine you say in any of them for Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Ayme, trat not worth a lowse, onely in my perigrination about le grand gloabe of de world, me find out a fine trick for make a de man, and Voman doe, dat is tickla in love.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: The man and the woman doe? how doe, how doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: To be cura, and all whole, Admirable vell.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: As how pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Me have had under my fingera, many brave vench, and most Noble gentle Dames, dat have bee much troubla, upon de wilde vorme in de taile for de man.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Very good.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: And bee my tra my Lord, by experement me finde dat de heart of de man; you understanda me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Yes, yes, the heart of the man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Wee wee, de heart of de man being all dry as peppera.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: So so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: And rub upon de ting (vat you call it) fall make it moulder all to crumble and dust.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Oh, oh, a Grater.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Ee by my tra you say vell, rub a de mans dry Art upon de Grater, and drinke de powder in de pot le Vine, by de Gen∣tle-voman, and by gars-blor, she present amently kick up de heele at de man she lova.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Excellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: No point more remembra, but cry out le French poo up∣on le varlet.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: So shee will hate her lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Be-gar, as my selfe hate le puz-cat, cry mew at my shin; and vill have de rombling a de gut, for de other gentle home.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Thou com'st up close to me now, my brave Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P:
Be-gar me hope so, and derfore my Lord apply le despe∣rate
Medicine, to le perilous maladie, and have dis Angelo be cut in de troate, and be man-slaughtered.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: You then advise me to have Angelo slaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang,
SP.L: Wee.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: And then to have my daughter drincke his heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Wee, wee.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Grated and dried, and so—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Wee, wee, wee.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: I wo'd I grip'd it fast now in this hand,
And eat it panting hot, to teach a peasant
To climbe above his being, Doctor, hee dies.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Knocka de pate downe be-gar.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: But stay, stay, hee's fled Florence; It will bee
A worke to find him first out, and being found,
A taske to kill him; for our Gallants speake
Much of his worth; The varlet is valiant.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: No matera for dat; for-two tree foure crowne, dar be
Rascalls fall run him in on de backe-shide.

SP.SPEAKER: Flor.
SP.L: He shall be sought for, and being found, he dies.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Pray my lor' suffera le Princesse and me for be in private,
Le Doctor uses for toucha doe Ooman—

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Doe, so, whil'st I for Angeloes death use speede,
For till I have his heart, mine owne must bleede.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Oh my Baptista.

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: I have heard the thunder aym'd at your life.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: And it will strike me dead,
With a most soddaine and Invisible blowe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: Now that you see his vengeance apt to fall,
Flie from it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: By fayre, and free accesse,
Open your dangers to your Mistris eyes,
Where shee starke mad, so she be mad for love,
You'le bring her to her witts, if wisely now
You put her intoth' way; Gold bar'd with locks,
Is best being stolne; steale her then.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: 'Tis but a wracke at most,
Oh on what boisterous Seas is True love tost!

DIV1.HEAD: Actus Tertius. Scaena prima.
DIV1.STAGE: Trumpets sounding. Enter an Vsher bare, perfuming a roome, Signi∣nior Torrenti gorgeously attyred, a company of Gallants.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: THis Roome smells.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Gal.
SP.L: It has bin new perfum'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.P: Then 'tis your breeches; stand off—and shines there (say you) a Sun in our horizon full as glorious, as we our selfe?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Gal.
SP.L: So cry the common people.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: The common people are Rascalls, lying devills,
Dung-hills, whose savor poisons brave mens fames,
That Ape of greatnesse (imitating mee)
I meane that slavish Lord Iacomo
Shall die a beggar, If at the yeares end,
His totall of expence dares equall mine;
How is his house built?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Gal.
SP.L: Admirable faire.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Faire? Ile guild mine (like Pompey's Theater)
All ore to out-shine his; the richest hangings
Persian, or Turke, or Indian slaves can weave,
Shall from my purse be bought at any rates;
Ile pave my great hall with a floare of Clowdes,
Wherein shall move an artificiall Sunne,
Reflecting round about me, golden beames,
Whose flames shall make the roome seeme all on fire,
And when 'tis night, just as that Sun goes downe,
A silver Moone shall rise, drawne up by starres,
And as that moves, I standing in her Orbe,
Will move with her, and be that man ith' moone,
So mock't in old wives tales; then over head,
A roofe of Woods, and Forests full of Deere,
Trees growing downwards, full of singing quiers.
And this i'le doe that men with prayse, may crowne
My fame, for turning the world upside downe:
And what brave gallants are Gentilies guestes?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Gal.
SP.L: The Lord Iacomo Gentili feeds
All Beggars at his Table.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Hang Iacome,
My boarde shalbe no manger for poore jades
To lick up provinder in.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Gal.
SP.L: He welcomes souldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Let souldiors beg and starue, or steale and hange.
Wo'd I had heere ten-thousand Souldiors heads,
Their sculs set all in silver, to drinck healthes
To his confusion, first invented warre,
And the health drunck to drowne the bowles i'th Sea,
That very name of Souldior, makes me shrugg,
And thinck I crawle with vermin; give me Lutes,
Mischiefe on drumms, for souldiors; fetch me whores,
These are mens blisse; those every Kingdomes soares,
Wee gave in charge to search through all the world
For the best Cookes, rarest musitians,
And fairest girles, that will sell sinne for gold.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Gal.
SP.L: Some of all sorts you have

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Let me have more
Then the grand Signior, And my change as rare,
Tall, low, and middle size, the browne, and faire;
Ide give a Princes ransome now to kisse
Blacke Cleopatra's cheeke; Onely to drinke
A richer perle, then that of Anthonyes,
That Fame (where his name stands) might put downe mine.
Oh that my Mother had bin Paris Whore,
And I had liv'd to see a Troy on fire,
So that by that brave light, I might have danc'd
But one Lavalto with my Curtezan.

SP.SPEAKER: 4. Gal.
SP.L: Patterne of all perfection breath'd in man,
There's one without, before your Excellence
Desires accesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: What creature?

SP.SPEAKER: 4. Gal.
SP.L: Your owne brother,
At least hee termes himselfe so.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Is he brave?

SP.SPEAKER: 4. Gal.
SP.L: Hee's new come from Sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: 'Tis true, that Iason
Rig'd out a Fleete to fetch the Golden-Fleece;
'Tis a brave boy, all Elementall fire,
His shipps are great with Child of Turkish Treasure,
And heere shall be delivered; marshall him in
Like the seas proud commander give our charge—

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Sound drums, and trumpets, for my Lord away.
SP.STAGE: Vsher him in Pare and ragged. At which Torrenti starts, his hat falls off, Offer it him.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Thou whorson pesant, know me, burne that wind-fall,
It comes not to my head that drops so low,—Another

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Gall.
SP.L: Hatts for my Lord,—Hatt's brought in 3. or 4.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: It smells of earth, stood it againe so high,
My head would on a dung-hill seeme to lie.
How now? what scar-crow's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: Scar-crow? thy brother,
His bloud cleare as thine owne, but that it smoakes not,
With perfum'd fiers as thine doth.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Has the poore snake, a sting; can he hisse?
What beggs the rogue for?

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: Vengeance
From the just thunderer to throw Lucifer downe;
How high so ever thou rearest thy Babell-browes,
To thy confusion I this language speake:
I am thy fathers sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Ha, ha, the Skipper raves.

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: The aw'd Venetian on St. Markes proud-day,
Never went forth to marry the rich-sea,
With casting in her lapp a ring of gold;
In greater bravery then my selfe did freight,
A fleete of gallant youthfull Florentines,
All vow'd to rescew Rhodes, from Turkish-slavery:
We went and waded up in our owne bloods,
Till most of us were drown'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Faire riddance on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: Where such a Peacock durst not spread his plumes;
We fought and those that fell left Monuments
Of unmatch't valour to the whole race of man,
They that were ta'ne, (mongst whom my selfe was chiefe)
Were three yeeres chain'd up to the tugging o're,
See here the relicts of that misery, Chaines,
If thou wu'd'st know more, reade it on my backe,
Printed with the Bulls-peezele.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Hang the dogge.
What tellest thou me of Peezeles?

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: 'Tis thy brother tells thee so, note me.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: I know thee not;
Set mastives on him, worry him from my gates.

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: The first unhappy breath I drew, mov'd heere,
And here I'le spend my last, e're brav'd from hence,
Heere I'le have meate and cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Kick the curre out.

SP.SPEAKER: Bro.
SP.L: Who dares?
Take from that sumpter-horses backe of thine,
Some of those gaudie trappings to cloathe mine,
And keepe it from the keene aire, fetch me food,
You fawning spaniells

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Gall.
SP.L: Some spirit of the buttery.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Gall.
SP.L: It should be by his hunger.

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: I am starv'd,
Thirsty, and pinde to th'bare bones, heere; I'le eate at thine
Owne scorneful board, on thine owne meate, or teare it from
Thy throate as 'tis chewing downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: I'le try that; if my dinner be prepared,
Serue me in my great state along'st this way,
And as you passe two there with pistolls stand.
To kill that ravenous Vulture; if he dare thrust his tallents
Forth to make one dish his prey.

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: Now view my face, and tho perhaps you shamd
To owne so poore a brother, let not my heart-strings,
In sunder cracke, if we now being lone,
You still disdaine me.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Wretch I know thee not,
And loath thy sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: Slave, thou shalt know me then;
I'le beate thy braines out with my Gally-chaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Wilt murther thine owne brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: Pride doth it selfe confound,
What with both hands the Devill strove to have bound,
Heaven with one little finger hath untyed,
This proves that thou maiest fall, because one blast
Shakes thee already, feare not, I'le not take
The whip out of your hand and tho' thou break'st
Lawes of humanitie, and brother-hood;
I'le not doe soe, but as a begger should
(Not as a brother) knock I at the gate
Of thy hard heart for pitty to come forth,
And looke upon my wretchednes, A shot
Toore to the keele that gally where I row'd;
Sunke her, the men slaine, I by dyving scaped,
And sat three leagues upon a broken-mast,
Wash't with the salt teares of the Sea, which wept,
In pitty, to behold my misery.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Pox on your, tarry misery.

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: And when heavens blest-hand hal'de me to a shoore
To dry my wet-limbes, was I forc'd to fire,
A dead-mans straw-bed throwne into the streete.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Foh, th'art infectious.

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: Oh remember this!
He that does good deeds, here waits at a Table,
Where Angells are his fellow servitours.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: I am no Robbin-red-breast to bring strawes
To cover such a coarse.

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: Thou art turn'd devill,
SP.STAGE: Trumpets sound. Enter an arm'd sewer, after him a company with covered dishes: Coronets on their heads. Two With pistolls to guard it.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Where's thy great stomack, eat, stand, let him choose
What dish he likes.—snatches a pistoll: ill flye off.

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: This then which I'le carve up
On thy base bosome, see thou Tryviall foole,
Thou art a Tyrant (o're me) of short reigne,
This cock out crow's thee, and thy petty kings,
Th'art a proud-bird, but fliest with rotten wings;
To shew how little for thy scorne I care,
See my revenge turn's all to idle-aire,
It upward flies and will from thence I feare
Shoote darts of lightning to confound thee heere.
Farewell thou huge Leviathan, when th'ast drunk dry,
That Sea thou rowl'st in, on some base shore dye.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Where is the Traitor?

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Now the house is fiered,

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: You come to cast on waters; barre up my doores,
But one such tattered ensigne here being spread,
Drawes numbers hither, here must no rogues be fed;
Command my carpenters invent od engines.
To manacle base beggers, hands and feete,
And by my name call'em my whipping posts;
If you spye any man that has a looke,
Stigmatically drawne, like to a furies,
(Able to fright) to such I'le give large pay,
To watch and ward for poore snakes night and day,
And whip'em soundly if they approch my gates;
The poore are but the earths-dung fit to lie
Cover d on much-heapes not to offend the eye.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Gall.
SP.L: Two Gentlemen sent from the Florence Duke,
Require speech with your Lord-ship—

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Give'm entrance
What re you? and whence come you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: From the Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Your businesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: This, fame sounding forth your worth
For hospitable princely house-keeping;
Our Duke drawne by the wonder of report,
Invites himselfe (by us) to be your guest.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: The honour of Embassadors be yours;
Say to the Duke that Caesar never came;
More welcome to the Capitoll of Rome,
Then he to us—healthes to him—fill rich wines.

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: You have this wonder wrought, now rare to men;
By you they have found the golden age agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Which I'le uphold, so long as there's a sunne,
To play the Alchymist.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: This proud fellow talkes
As if he grasped the Indies in each hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: Health to your Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Amb.
SP.L: We pledge it on our knees.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: I'le stand to what I do, but kneele to none.
SP.STAGE: Musicke, drinck, breake the glasse, they pledge it in plate, Which offering, both servitours refuse to take.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Breake not our custome (pray ye) with one beame;
The god of mettailes makes both gold and wine
To Imitate whose greatnesse; If on you
I can bestow Wine, I can give gold too,
Take them as free as Bacohus spends his blood;
And in them drinke our health.

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: Your bounty farre
Exceeds that of our Caesars.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Caesar ero, vel nihil ero:
What are Gold heapes? but a rich dust for Kings
To scatter with their breath, as chaffe by winde?
Let him then that hath gold, beare a Kings minde,
And give till his arme akes, who bravely powres
But into a wenches lap his golden showres,
May be Ioves equall, oh but hee that spends
A world of wealth, makes a whole world his debter,
And such a Noble spender is Ioves better;
That man Ile be, I'me Alexanders heire
To one part of his minde, I wish there were
Ten Worlds, yet not to conquer, but to sell.
For Alpine hills of silver, And that I.
Might at one feast, spend all that treasure drie;
Who hoards up wealth, is base; who spends it, brave,
Earth breeds gold, so I tread but on my slave;
Beare backe our gratulations to your Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Amb.
SP.L: Wee shall great sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: Torrenti call you him; 'tis a prowd rough streame.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Hee's of the Romane Family indeede.

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: Lord Vanni? rather my Lord Vanitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: And heapes of money sure have strucke him mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: Hee'le soone pick up his witts, let him but bleede
Thus many ownces at one time; All day
Could I drinke these deare healthes, yet nere be drunke.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: And carry it away most cleanely.

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: Not a pin the worse;
What might his father leave him?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: A great estate,
Of some 300000 Crownes a yeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: Strange hee's not begg'd, for fooles are now growne
An admirable Cocks-combe! (deare;

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Let wonder passe,
Hee's both a brave-Lord, and a golden Asse.
SP.STAGE: A Bed discovered, Eyametta upon it. Enter two Dukes, Piero, Gallants, Nurse, Ladies, Angelo, Baptista, ut antea Fyametta.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: I pray you hush all, a little hush, le faire Lady by hee owne vo unter disposition, has take a ting dat is of such a grand operation, it shall make a de stone for slepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: What, Noble Doctor, is the name of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Tis not your fcurvie English Poppy, nor Mandragon, nor a ting so danger as Oppium, but tis de brave ting a de vorld, for knock a de braine asleepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: I am glad shee takes this rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Peace, be gor it is snore and snore, two mile long; now if your grace vill please for procure Musick, be restore as brave as de fish.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Call for the Musicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Makea no noise, but bring in de Fidlers, and play sweet▪

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.P: Oh out upon this Doctor; hang him, does he thinke to cure dejected Ladies with Fidlers—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: De grand French poo stopa de troate, pray void le Shambera.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: All, all part softly; peace Nurse, let her sleepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurs.
SP.P: I, I, go out of her prospect, for shee's not to bee cur'd with a song.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Baptista, see the doore fast, watch that narrowly.

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.P: For one friend to keepe doore for another, is the office now amongst gallants, common as the Law; Ile bee your por∣ter Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Shee does but slumber, Fiametta, Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: The Pisan Prince comes: daggers at my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Looke up, I am not hee, but Angelo?

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Ha! who names Angelo?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Angelo himselfe,
Who with one soote treads on the throat of death,
Whilst t'other stepps to embrace thee, thus ith' shape
Of a French Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Oh my life, my soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Heare me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: I me now not sicke, Ile have no Phisicke,
But what thy selfe shall give mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Let not Ioy confound our happinesse, I am but dead,
If it be knowne I am heere.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Thou shalt not hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Be wise deare heart; see here the best of men,
Faithfull Baptista———

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Oh, I love Baptista,
Cause he loves thee; But my Angelo I love bove kings.

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: Madam you'le spoile,
Vnlesse you joyne with us in the safe plot
Of our escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Sweete Fyametta heare me.
For you shall hence with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Over ten worlds,
But Ile not hence; my Angelo shall not hence,
True love, like gold, is best being tried in fire;
Ile defie Father, and a thousand deaths—for thee——

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Vndone, vndone.

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: At the Court gate,
I see a Iebbit already, to hang's both;
Death! the Duke beates at the doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: He shall come in;
One frowne at thee, my Tragedie shall begin;
See Father—

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: I told you that I heard—her tongue—

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: See Father. Flo. What sweete girle?

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: That's Angelo, and you shall pardon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Hee sayes hee pardons thee with all his heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Mee Lor, be all mad, le braine crowe, and run whirabout like de windmill saile, pardon a moy, por quoy my sweete Ma∣dam, pardon your povera Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Because thou art my banish't Angelo.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Starke mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: This her recoverie?

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Hee is no Doctor,
Nor that his man, but his deare friend Baptista;
Has black't this beard like a Comoedian
To play the Mountibanke; avvay, Ile marry
None but that Doctor, and leave Angelo.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: I doe pray Artely, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Leave off thy gibberishe, and I prethee speake
Thy Native language.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Par-ma-soy all French be-gor sheebe mad as the moone.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Sweet girle, with gentle hands sir, take her hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Stand from mee, I must follow Angelo.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: Thine eyes drinke sleepe from the sweet god of rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Oh, you shoote poyson'd arrowes thorow my breast.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: What strange new furie now possesseth her?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Begar her imaginashon be out a de vitts, and so dazell de two nyes, and come downe so into de bellie, and possibla for make her tinke mee or you to be le shentle-man shee lovea, and so shee takea my man for a Iack-a-nape, mee know not who.

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: For one Baptista.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Povera garshon a my trat.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: I doe beleeve you both, but honest Doctor,
Straine all thy Art, and so thou leave her well,
I care not if you call up feinds from hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Dar be too much devill in de body all ready be my trat my Lor, mee no stay heere for ten hundred hundred Coronaes, she cry upon mee 'tis Master Angelo, you tink so not one and two time, but a tyrd time, you smell a me out; And so cutta my troate; adue my Lor.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Still your opinion holds to kill that villaine,
And give her his heart dried.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: In de pot a vine, wee, very fine.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: This gold take for thy paines to make her sownde,
There needs a desperate cure to a desperate wounde.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: How blowes it now?

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: Faire, with a prosperous gale.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Poore love, thou still art strucke with thine owne fate;
My life hangs at a thred, friend I must flie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SP.L: How, to be safe?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: I will take sanctuary,
I know a reverend Fryar, in whose cell
Ile lurke till stormes blow ore; If women knew
What men feele for them, None their scornes should rue.
SP.STAGE: Enter Tibaldo in Womans attire, Alphonsina.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.P:
Is't come to this, have the walls of the Castle beene besie∣ged
thus long, lien open for a breach; and dare you not
SP.L: Give fier to once piece? oh y'ar a proper soldyor, good
Sister, brother follow your game more close, or i'le leave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: What wu'd you have me doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: Why I would ha'you (tho'you be in womans apparrell) to be your selfe a man, and do what you come for.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: I have bin giving her a thousand on setts,
And still a blushing cheeke makes me retire;
I speake not three words, but my tongue is ready
To aske forgivenes of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: Must thou needs at thy first encounter tell her thou art a man, why when you walke together, cannot you begin a tale to her, with once upon a time there was a loving couple that ha∣ving tyred themselves with walking, sat downe upon a banck, and kist, and embraced, and plaid, and so by degrees bring the tale about to your owne purpose. Can you not? fie, you are the worst at these things Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: I am sister indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: And the more foole you indeed: you see how the old stinking fox her husband is stil rubbing me as if I had the palsy, Ile not have his wither'd hands (which are as moist as the side of stock-fish) lye pidling in my bosome, therefore determine some thing, or farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: I have deare sister, if you will but heare me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Come on, out with't then.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Give you the old man promise of your love,
And the next night appoint him for your bed;
Rap'd with joy, he'le seigne businesse of state,
To leave his lady, and to lie alone,

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Very good.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Then my request shall be, that for that night
She would accept me for her bed-fellow,
And there's no question sister of the grant,
Which being Injoy'd I doubt not but to manage
And carry all so even on levill ground,
That my offence shall in my love seeme drownde.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: The clocke for your businesse thus far goes true, but now for me, what shall I do with the old cock in my Roost?

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Sister, you have some tricke (no doubt) to keepe
Him within compasse.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P:
No not I beleeve me, I know not what to doe with him,
unlesse I should give him a little Nux vomica, to make him sleep away the night, but brother, to pleasure you, Ile venter a joynte, and yet it troubles me too, that I should prove a Traytor to my sex, I doe betray an Innocent Lady, to what ill I know not.
SP.L: But Love the author of it wil I hope
Turne it quite otherwise, and perhaps it may be
So welcome to her as a courtesie.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: I doubt not but it shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: We nothing can,
Vnlesse man woman helpe, and woman man.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus quartus. Scaenaprima.
DIV1.STAGE: Trumpets sounding. Enter Torrenti very brave, betweene the two Dukes, attended by all the Courtiers, wondring at his costly ha∣bit. Enter a mask, woman in strang habitts, Danee. Exit. He gives jewells, and ropes of pearle to the Duke; and a chaine of gold to every Courtier. Exit. Nicholett and he stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: THou art my noble kinsman, and but thy mother
(Vpon my soule) was chast I should beleeve
Some Emperor begot thee,

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Why pray Vncle?

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: Suppose all kingdomes on the earth were balls,
And that thou held'st a racket in thy hand,
To tosse 'em as thou wu'd'st, how wo'dst thou play?

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Why? as with balls, bandy 'em quite away.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: A tennes-court of kings could do no more;
But faith what doest thou thinke, that I now think,
Of thy this days expence?

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: That it was brave.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: I thinke thee a proud vaine-glorious bragging knaue,
That golden wombe thy father left so full, thou
Vulture-like eat'st thorough: oh heeres trimstuffe;
A good-mans state, in Gartyres, strings and ruffe;
Hast not a saffron shirt on too? I feare th'art
Troubled with the greene-sicknes, thou look'st wan.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: With anger at thy snarling must my hoase
Match your old greasy cod-piece?

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: No, but I'de have thee live in compasse.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Foole, I'le be
As the sun in the Zodiack; I am he
That wood take Phaetons fall, tho' I set fire
On the whole world to be heavens charioteire,
(As he was) but one day.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: Vaine riotous cockscombe,
Tha'st fier'd to much already, Parkes, Forrests, chases,
Have no part left of them, but names and places;
'Tis voic'd abroad thy lands are all at pawne.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: They are, what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: And that the mony went to
Entertaine the Popes great Nuntio,
On whom you spent the ransome of a king.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: You lye.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: I thanke you Sr,

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Say all this true
That I spent millions, what's that to you.
Were there for every day i'th'yeare a Pope,
For every houre i'th'yeare a Cardinall;
I'd melt both Indies, but I'de feast'em all.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: And leave your Curtezans bare, that leaving bare,
Will one day leave thee naked, one nights waking,
With a fresh-whore, cost thee 4000. duckets,
Else the bawd lies.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Wert thou not mine uncle
I'de send thee with thy frozen-beard where furies
Should sindge it off with fire-brands, touching
Wenching, that art thy selfe an old rotten whore-master.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: I a whore-master?
To shew how much I hate it, harke, when next thy tomblers
Come to dance upon the ropes,
Play this jigg to 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: Goe, goe, idle droane,
Thou enviest bees with stings, because thine is gone,
Plate, jewells, revenues all shall flie.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: They shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Tor.
SP.L: And then Sir I'le turne pickled theefe, a Pirate,
For as I to feed Rayot, a world did crave,
So nothing but the sea shall be my grave,
Meane time that circle few began l've runne, tho' the
Devill stand i'th' Center.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: What's that circle?

SP.SPEAKER: Torr.
SP.L: The vanitie of all man-kinde be mine,
In me all prodigalls loosenes fresh shall flowe,
Wine, harlots, surfetts, rich embroidered cloaths,
Fashions, all sensuall sins, all new coin'd oathes,
Shall feed me, fill me; Ile feast every sence,
Nought shall become me ill, but innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: I hope a wallet hanging at thy backe,
Who spends all young, ere age comes, all will lacke.
SP.STAGE: Enter an Apothecary give a serving-man gold, Iacomo, Servants in blew-coats: Stew. Broker, Goldsmith, Torrenti's Brother, a Trumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: What sounds this trumpet for?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Dinner my Lord,

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: To feast whome this day are my tables spread?

SP.SPEAKER: St.
SP.L: For sea-men, wrack't, aged, or sicke, or lame,
And the late ransom'd captives from the Turke.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Cheere them with harty welcomes in my name,
Attend them as great Lords, let no man dare,
To send'em sad hence, bounty shall be plac'd
At the boards upper end; For Marriners
Are clocks of danger that do ne're stand still,
Their dialls-hand ere points to'th stroke of death,
And (albeit seldome windlesse) loose their breath;
I love'em, for they eat the dearest bread,
That life can buy, when the elements make warrs;
Water and aire, they are sayd by their good starrs.
And for the gally-slaves, make much of those, love that man
Who suffers onely for being christian; What suiters waite?

SP.SPEAKER: St.
SP.L: Come neere, one at once, keep back pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Bro.
SP.L: A sorry man, a very sorry man.

SP.SPEAKER: Gen.
SP.L: What makes thee sorry?

SP.SPEAKER: Brok.
SP.P: All I had is burnt, and that which touches me to the quick, a boxe of my sweete evidence my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Show me some proofe of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Brok.
SP.L: Alas too good proofe, all burnt, nor stick, nor stone, left.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: What wodst have me doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Brok.
SP.L: Bestow but a bare 100. l. on me, to set me up.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Steward deliver him a 100. l.

SP.SPEAKER: Brok.
SP.L: Now all the—

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Nay kneele not Sir, but heare me.

SP.SPEAKER: Brok.
SP.L: Oh my hony Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Faces are speaking pictures, thine's a booke,
Which if the leafe be truly printed shews
A page of close dissembling.

SP.SPEAKER: Brok.
SP.L: Oh my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: But say thou art such, yet the monie's thine,
Which I to Charitie give, not to her shrine;
If thou cheat'st me, thou art cheated? how? th'hast got
(Being licorish) rats-bane from a gally-pot,
Taking it for sugar; thou art now my debtor,
I am not hurt, nor thou I feare, much better; farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Soul.
SP.L: Cannons defend me, Gun-powder of hell,
Whom doest thou blow up heere?

SP.SPEAKER: Break.
SP.L: Some honest scullar, row this lame dog to hanging.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: What noise is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Stew.
SP.L: My Lord calls to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Soul.
SP.L: Was there ever call'd
A devill by name from hell? then this is one.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: My friend, what is hee?

SP.SPEAKER: Soul.
SP.L: A Citie pestilence,
A moath that eates up gownes, doublets and hose,
One that with Bills, leades smocks and shirts together
To linnen close adultery, and upon them
Strowes lavender, so strongly, that the owners
Dare never smell them after; hee's a broaker.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Suppose all this, what hurt hath hee done thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Soul.
SP.L: More then my limbs losse; in one weeke he eate
My wife up, and three children, this christian Iew did;
Ha's a long lane of hellish Tenements,
Built all with pawnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Gen.
SP.L: All that he had is burnt.

SP.SPEAKER: Soul.
SP.L: He keepes a whore indeede, this is the Raven,
Cryed knocke before you call, he may be fir'd,
His lowsie wardropes are not; to this hell-hound
I pawn'd my weapons to buy browne bread
To seede my brats and me; (they forfited)
Twice so much as his money him I gave,
To have my Armes redeem'd, the griping slave
Swore (not to save my soule) vnlesse that I
Laid downe my stumpe heere, for the Interest,
And so hop home.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Vnheard of villain!
Broker, is this true?

SP.SPEAKER: Brok.
SP.L: 'Twere sinne my Lord, to lie.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Souldier, what is't thou now crau'st at my hands?

SP.SPEAKER: Soul.
SP.L: This my Pitition was, which now I teare,
My suite here was, When the next place did fall,
To be a Beades-man in your Hospitall:
But now I come most pitiously complaining
Against this three-pile rascall, widowes decayer,
The Orphans beggerer, and the poores betrayer;
Give him the Russian law for all these sinnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Soul.
SP.L: But one hundred blowes on his bare shins

SP.SPEAKER: Br.
SP.L: Come home and take thine Arms.

SP.SPEAKER: So.
SP.L: Ile have those leggs

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Broaker, my soule foresaw goods thus ill got,
Would as ill thrive, you ask'd a hundred pound,
'Tis yours; but crafty Broaker, you plaid the knave
To begg, not needing. This man now must have
His request too, 'tis honest, faire, and just,
Take hence that varlet therefore, and on his shinnes,
In ready payment, give him an hundred blowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Rroak.
SP.L: My Lord, my pitifull Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Soul.
SP.L: I must bestirre my stumps too. Iustice; my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: I will not ravill out time; Broaker, I offer you
A hundred for a hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: Soul.
SP.L: That's his owne usury.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: A hundred pound, or else a hundred blowes,
Give him that money, he shall release you those.

SP.SPEAKER: Brok.
SP.L: Take it, and may'st thou rot with't.

SP.SPEAKER: Soul.
SP.L: Follow thee thy curse,
Wo'd blowes might make all Broakers still disburse.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: What next?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.L: The Party sir:

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: What party sir?
If honest, speake, I love no whisperer.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.L: This Gentleman is a great shuter.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: In a Long-bow? how farre shootes hee?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.L: To your Lordship, to be your Apothecary.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Vmph; what spie you in my face, that I sho'd buy
Your druggs and drenches? beares not my cheeke a colour
As fresh as any old mans? doe my bones
Ake with youth's ryotts? or my blood boile hot
With seavers? or is't num'd with dropsies, cold
Coughes, Rhumes, Catarrhes, Gowts, Apoplexie fits?
The common soares of age, on me never ran,
Nor Galenist, nor Paracelsian,
Shall ere reade Phisicall Lecture upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Apot.
SP.L: Two excellent fellowes my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: I honour their profession,
What the Creator does, they in part doe,
For a Phisician's a man-maker too,—but honest friend,
My kitchin is my Doctor, and my Garden,
Trustie Apothecarie; when they give me pills,
So gently worke they, I'me not choak'd with bills,
Which area stronger purge then the disease.

SP.SPEAKER: Apo.
SP.L: Alas my Lord, and 'twere not for bills, our shops wo'd

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Sir, I beleeve you, bills nor pills Ile take; (downe.
I stand on sicknes shoare, and see men tost
From one disease to another, at last lost;
But to such seas of surfetts, where they're drown'd,
I never ventering, am ever sound.

SP.SPEAKER: Apo.
SP.P: Ever sound my Lord? if all our gallants sho'd bee so, Do∣ctors, Pothecaries, and Barber-surgeons, might feed upon Ony∣ons and Butter-milke; ever sound! a brave world then.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: 'Tis their owne fault, if they feare springs or falls,
Wine-glasses fill'd too fast, make urynalls;
Man was at first borne sound, and hee growes ill
Seldome by course of nature, but by will—
Distempers are not ours, there should be then
(Were wee our selues) no Phisicke, men to men
Are both diseases cause, and the disease,
I'me free from (thankes good fate) either of these.

SP.SPEAKER: Apo.
SP.L: My 50. Crownes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Apo.
SP.L: No, must I give you a Glister?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Hist, hist.

SP.SPEAKER: Apo.
SP.P: If your Lordship will not allow me minister to your selfe, pray let me give your man a purgation.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Me a Purgation? my Lord, I'me passing well.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Him a Purge, why?

SP.SPEAKER: Apo.
SP.L: Or rather a vomit, that hee may cast up 50 Crownes—
Which he swallowed as a Bribe to preferre me.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: My health is bought and sold sir then by you,
A Doctor baits you next, whose mesh of potions
Striking me full of vlcers, a gibberish Surgion,
For 50. Crownes more, comes to drawe my will,
For mony, slaves their Soveraignes thus kill;
Nay, nay, so got, so keepe it; for his Fifty,
Give him a 100. Crownes, because his will
Aym'd at my health I know, and not at ill:
Fare you well sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Apo.
SP.L: Who payes mee sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Follow me, I sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gold.
SP.L: The fellow, my Lord, is fast.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: What fellow sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Gold.
SP.L: The thiefe that stole this Iewell from your honour,
Hee came unto my stall my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: So.

SP.SPEAKER: Gold.
SP.L: And ask'd mee
Not the fourth part in money it was worth,
And so smelling him out.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: You did.

SP.SPEAKER: Golds.
SP.L: I did sir,
