Smell him out presently, and under hand
Sent for a Constable, examined him,
And finding that he is your Stewards man,
Committed him toth' Iale.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: What money had hee upon this Iewell of you?

SP.SPEAKER: Golds.
SP.L: None my good Lord, after I heard it yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Else you had bought it,
And beene the thiefes receiver, y'ar a varlet,
Go to, a sawcie knave; if I want money;
And send my servants servant (cause the world
Shall not take notice of it) to pawne, or sell
Iewells, or Plate, tho' I loose halfe in halfe,
Must you sir, play the Marshall, and commit him,
As if he were a rogue; goe and release him,
Send him home presently, and pay his fees, doe you see sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gold.
SP.L: My Lord, I do see.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Least by the Innocent fellow,
I lay you fast byth' heeles, doe this y'are best;
You may be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Gold.
SP.L: Heere's a most excellent jeast.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Harke you, the Duke of Florence sent me once
A Iewell, have ye'it? For you laid it up.

SP.SPEAKER: Ste.
SP.L: My Lord, I have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Are you sure you have it?
Why change you colour? Know you this? doe you know
Your man, you sent to sell it? You belike
Thought in my memory it had beene dead,
And so your honesty too came buried,
'Tis well, out of mine eye; what wo'd you with mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: Your pitty on a wretch late wrackt at sea,
Beaten a shore by penury, 3▪ yeares a Turkish
Gally-slave.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Your birth?

SP.SPEAKER: Broth.
SP.L: Such Sir,
As I dare write my selfe a gentlema,
In Florence stood my cradle, my house great,
In mony, not in mercy; I am poore,
And dare not with the begger passe their doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Name them, they shalbe forc't to thy reliefe.
To steale compassion from them like a thiefe,
Good my Lord pardon me, under your noble wing,
I had rather sit, then on the highest tree sing,
That shadowes their gay buildings.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Young man I doe commend thee, where's my steward?
Give me thy hand, I entertaine thee mine,
Make perfect your accounts, and see the books deliver'd
To this Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: St.
SP.L: This poore rogue Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Thou art a villaine, so to tearme the man,
Whom I to liking take; Sir I discharge you;
I regard no mans out-side, 'tis the lineings
Which I take care for,

SP.SPEAKER: St.
SP.L: Not if you knew how louzie they were.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Cast not thy scorne upon him, prove thou but just,
Ile raise the Cedars spring out first from dust.
SP.STAGE: Enter Nicolletto, Dariene, Alphons, Alisandra, Tibaldo, Cargo.

SP.SPEAKER: Nie.
SP.L: Madam this night I have received from court,
A booke of deepe import, which I must reade,
And for that purpose will I he alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Dar.
SP.L: Be Mr. of your owne content my Lord.
Ile change you for some femall bed-fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Pray madam then take me.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Doe prethee wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Dar.
SP.L: And Sr. she is most welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Wo'ld I were at it, for it is a booke,
My fingers itch till I be turning o're;
Good rest faire Alphonsina you'le not faile.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: No, feare me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: All all to bed, to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Mine eyes are full of sleepe; Ile follow you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dar.
SP.L: I to my closet, and then bed-fellow
Expect your company

SP.SPEAKER: Tibal.
SP.L: I will be for your Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Aless.
SP.L: Madam so please you forfeit to my mother,
And let your selfe and I be bed-fellowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Deare heart I humbly thanke you, but I must not.

SP.SPEAKER: Aless.
SP.L: Lady I rather wish your company,
Because I know one maiden best conceales,
What's bosom'd in another: but Ile waite
With patience a time fitting.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Worthy Lady,
This time is yours and mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Aless.
SP.L: Thus I begin then,
And if I cannot woe reliefe from you,
Let me at least win pitty, I have fixt
Mine eye upon your brother; whom I never
But once beheld here in this house yet wish
That he beheld me now and heard me;
You are so like your brother, that me thinkes I speake to him,
And that provokes a blush to assaile my cheeke;
He smiles like you, his eyes like you; pray Lady
Where is the gentleman? 'twas for his sake
SP.P: I would have lien with you, wo'd it were as lawfull to fellow nights with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Troth I do wish it.

SP.SPEAKER: Aless.
SP.L: And if in this you inrich me with your counsell, Ile
Be a gratefull taker.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Sure my brother
Is blest in your affection, and shall have
Good time to understand so.

SP.SPEAKER: Dar.
SP.L: Alesandra

SP.SPEAKER: Aless.
SP.L: Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Dar.
SP.L: A word, come quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.P: O ye heavens! how strangely one houre works upon an other. It was but now heart-sick, and long'd for meat,
SP.L: Which being set before me I abhorre.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: What frights you thus from your chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Such a fury as thou.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: How now? hast lost thy witts?

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Ile sweare thou hast, for thou hast candled
Thy sweete but poysonous language to dishonour
Me thy most wretched sister, who no better then a vile
Instrument to thy desires, deserves to be stil'd,
Baud, worse then the bauds.
Who every day i'th'weeke shake hands with hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Ha' patience dearest sister; I protest,
By all the graces that become a man,
I have not wrong'd Dariene nor her Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Thou shalt not then by heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: By all goodnes, not
With a well blush discourse faire Alissandra
Supposing me your sister hath discover'd
The true pangs of her fancy towards Tibaldo,
And in it crav'd my aide, which heard, Even then,
My Brutish purpose broke its neck, and I
Will proue the daughters husband, that came hither,
A traytour to the Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: My noble brother,
Our doings are alike, for by Trebatio
(Whome I with honour name) his fathers foulenes shall be
Cut off and crost.

SP.SPEAKER: Tib.
SP.L: Get to your chamber;
No longer will I play the womans part,
This night shall change my habit with my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Nichol.
SP.P: In this chamber she lies, and that's her window wo'd I were in: the aire bites, but the bit that I shall bite anon sharpens. my stomack, the watch-word is a cornet, (Cornet within) it speakes, she bids me come without a lighr, and reason snes light enough herselfe; wincke thou one-eyed baud, be thou an em∣bleme of thy Mr. and burne in secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: What sayes my most moist-handed sweete Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Who is there with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: No christian creature, I enter solus.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: I feare I must entreate you to stay a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: As long as thou desir'st, but-wilt come downe?

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: I would be loth to loose all upon rest,

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Shall I mount then?

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: For mine honour being once crack't.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Crack a pudding: Ile not meddle with thine honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Say you should get me with childe.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: I hope I am not the first Lord has got a lady with childe.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Is the night hush't?

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Ther's nothing stirring, the very mice are a sleeepe, as I am noble, Ile deale with thee like a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: Ile doe that then, which some Citizens will not doe, to some Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Take your word, I come.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: Vd's my life!

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: What's the matter sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: I heare a lute, and sure it comes this way.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.P: My most lov'd Lord, step you aside, I would not have you seene for the saving of my right hand, preserve mine honour, as I preserve your love.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: Pox on your Catts guts.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: To an unworthy window, who is thus kind?

SP.SPEAKER: Treb.
SP.L: Looke out of it, and 'tis the-richest casement
That ever let in Ayre.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Trebatio.

SP.SPEAKER: Treb.
SP.L: I, my most faire Mistris.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Neither of both good sir;
Pray play upon some other, you a buse mee,
And that which seemes worse, in your fathers house.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: Brave girle.

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: But you are young enough to be forgiven,
If you will mend hereafter, the night has in it
Vnwholsome foggs, and blasts; to bed my Lord,
Least they attach your beautie: nothing more,
Ile pay you for your song.

SP.SPEAKER: Treb.
SP.L: Are you gone so?
Well, you hard-hearted one, you shall not ever
Be Lady of your selfe—away.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Oh my Lord, I have stood Centinell as you bad me, but I am frighted.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: With what?

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: The Night-mare rides you, my Lady is conjured up.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Now the devill lay her down, prevented in the very Act.

SP.SPEAKER: Carg.
SP.L: She workes by magick, and knowes all.

SP.SPEAKER: Dari.
SP.L: Doe you shrinke backe my Lord? you may with shame;
Have I tane you napping my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: But not with the manner my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Dar.
SP.P: Have you no bird to flie at, but what sits on your owne sonnes fiste?

SP.SPEAKER: Nicho.
SP.L: How! my sonnes fiste? (Harlot

SP.SPEAKER: Darie.
SP.L: Yes, the Lady whom you wrought to have bin your
Your sonne has long since wonne to be his bride,
Both they and I have this night exercis'd
Our witts to mocke your dotage.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: Am I then gull'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Dare.
SP.P: Yes my Lord, and bull'd too, yonders Tibaldo Neri come this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Dare.
SP.L: So early, Is his sister with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Not that I saw, but I saw him kisse my yong Mistris, three or foure times, I thinke 'twere good to aske the banes of Matri∣mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.P: Wo't twere no worse, let's in, and give 'em the mornings Salutation.

SP.SPEAKER: Dare.
SP.L: Ile tell him all.

SP.SPEAKER: Nicho.
SP.L: Sweete Lady, seal my pardon with a kisse,
He ne're was borne, that never did amisse.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus quintus. Scaena prima.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Florence, Piero, Pisa, Mutio, Tornelli, Philippe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: SIr, I have found Angelo with long and busie search.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: And will he come?

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Your honour (as you charg'd me) I impawn'd
For his safe passage.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: By my life hee shall; when will hee come?

SP.SPEAKER: Pie.
SP.L: My friend brings him along.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Philippo Mutio, goe and perswade our daughter
To walke, and take the ayre.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: Ile play that Orator.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Attend the Duke of Pisa; prethee Piero
Discover where this Angelo lay lurking.

SP.SPEAKER: Pie.
SP.L: The world he has shut up, and now the booke
He reades, is onely heere, see where he comes.
SP.STAGE: Enter Angelo as a Fryar, Fyametta.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Way for my daughter; looke you, there's Angelo.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Ha? yes, 'tis the starre I saile by; hold me not,
Why doe you sticke like rocks, to barre my way,
And utterly to wracke mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Art thou mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Yes, I am mad, oh my best life, my soule!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Whom seeke you Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Doe you not know me sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Doest thou not love mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: At very heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Yes, at the very soule!

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Burnes not your love,
With that most holy fire, the god of marriage
Kindles in man and woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Noe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Ha, no?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Hee sayes no.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Then so, quod dedi perdidi.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: How can I love you Lady?
I have clim'd too many of such fruitlesse trees.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Have you indeede?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Yes, and have pull'd the apples.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Now I beshrew your fingers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: And when I touch'd 'em, found 'em turn'd to dust.
Why should you love me? I have chang'd my pleasure
In beautious dames, more then I have my dreames,
Foure in one night.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Hee'le prove a lustie Larrence;
This is the starre you sayle by tho.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang
SP.L: Why should you love me? I am but a Tombe,
Gay out-side, but within, rotten and foule.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Ile sweare th'art most diseas'd, even in thy soule;
Oh thou, thou most perfidious man alive,
So prosper, as my poore sicke heart doth thrive;
Give me thy hand, I hate thee, fare-thee-well.
Come, I make thee my heaven, wer't once my Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: I'me rap't above the spheares, Ioy strikes me dumbe.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: T'hast lent unto mine age a score of yeares,
More then ere nature promis'd, by thy loving
This Noble Prince; th'art his then?

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: His—to prove it; hence
Thou from mee; ne're more behold mine eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Now finde I, that a Loversheart last dies.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: I, I, so, so; If it die, it shall be buried.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: Good reverend Sir, stay you, and as you witnesse
This my divorce, so shall you seale my contract.

SP.SPEAKER: Fryar.
SP.L: I will, your pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Fyametta,
Make choice thy selfe of thine owne wedding day.

SP.SPEAKER: Fya.
SP.L: To morrow be it, Loves poyson is delay,
Gallants, pray stirre betimes, and rowse your Mistresses;
Let some invite Lord Vanni and his Lady;
Wee dine to day with Lord Iacomo,
Thither let's hasten: Sir, this holy man,
Shall be this night my confessor; about mid-night,
Expect my sending for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fryer.
SP.L: Your devotion
Commands my service. W'are least i'th fryers stead.
The Prince be your confessor; girle prepare
To play the bride tomorrow, and then being laid,
Oe night past o're thinke nere to rise a maide.
SP.STAGE: Trumets sounding services carried coverd over the stage, Poore at∣tending Torrents one, then enter acomo bare betwixt the two Duks, Piero, Philippo, Tornelli, Mutio.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: No more of complement, my Lord Gentili;
Such noble welcomes have we had this day,
We must take blushing leaves, cause we can pay
Nothing but thanks.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: That's more then the whole debt comes to,
Ne're saw I tables crown'd with braver store;
I know no man that spends my nor gives more,
And yet a ful sea still: why yonder fellow,
The brave mok-prodigall has spent all indeed,
He that made beggers proud, begs now himselfe for need.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: But who releeves him now? none, for I know
He that in riotous feasting, wastes his store,
Is like a faire tree which in sommer bore
Boughes laden till they crackt, with leaves and fruite;
Whose plenty lasting, all men came unto 't;
And pluckt and filld their lapps and carry away;
But when the boughes grow bare, and leaves decay:
And the great tree stands saplesse, wither'd dry,
Then each one casts on it a scornfull eye,
And grieves to see it stand, nay do not greeve,
Albeit the Axe downe to the roote it cleave;
The fall of such a tree, will I beware,
I know both when to spend, and when to spare.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: 'Tis nobly spoke

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: Nay good my Lord make hast.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Here's a childe lost i'th staying.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Get 2. at night for't.
What is the bride yet drest?

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: She's rigging Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: 'Tis well, musicke? from whence?
What chambers that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: It Ioynesclose to the
Lodgings of the bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Inquire.
If she be ready, Mutio, say her bride-groome
Attends on her below.

SP.SPEAKER: Mut.
SP.L: I shall my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Tarry, she looks her selfe out.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Come, come loiterer;

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Faire welcome to your grace, and to that Prince,
That should have bin my bridegroome.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Should ha beene?

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Is the Moone chang'd already?

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: In her changes the
Moone is constant, man is onely varying,
And never in one Circle long is tarying,
But one man in the moone at once appeares,
Such praise (being true to one) a woman beares.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Take thou that praise and to this Prince be true,
Come downe and marry him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: What would the world say,
If I should marry two men in one day?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: That villaine has bewitch't her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Sir what villaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: That slave, the banisht runnagate.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Cast not on him
Such foule aspersions, till you know his guilt;
Even now you said he was a worthy spirit,
Crown'd him with praise, and do you now condemne
An absent man unheard?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Ile hang thee traitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: Locke all the gates of Florence, least he scape.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Our pardon, whosoever takes and kill him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Oh! who would trust in Princes, the vaine breath,
Who in a minute gives one man life and death?

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Come forth thou threatned man, here kill him all,
Lower then what you stand on▪ none can fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: I now must stand your arrowes, but you shoote
Against a breast as innocent—

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: As a traytors.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Your patience Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: Talk'st thou of patience? that by thy most perfidious—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: Heare me pray.
Or if not me, heare then this reverend man.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: VVhat makes that Fryer there?

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Father speake your minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Fryer.
SP.L: I was enjoyned to be her confessor,
And came but then she wonn me to a vow,
By oath of all my orders, face to face,
To heare her speak unto Angelo, 'twas done,
He came, when falling downe on both her knees,
Her eyes drown'd all in teares, she opes a booke,
Chardging him read his oaths and promises,
The contract of their hands, hearts, yea and soules,
And askd if Angelo would marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Very good.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: He looking pale as death, said faintly no.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: Faintly, he then was willing?

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Pray heare him out.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: Thrice tried: he thrice cried no; At which this Ladie
Desperately snatching from her side two knives,
Had stab'd her selfe to th'heart, but that we knit
Our force against it, what should I doe in this?
Not marry her, or rob her of heavens blisse?
Which glory had bin greater to have tane,
A husband from her, or to have seene her slaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Then you have married her?

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: I have.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Brave girle.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: Ile cut that knot asunder with my sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Fry.
SP.L: The hands which heaven hath joyn'd, no man can part.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: The hands they may, but never shall the heart,

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Why didst thou make to him thy promise then?

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Women are borne, but to make fooles of men.
She that's made sure to him, she loves not well,
Her banes are ask'd here, but she wedds in hell;
Parents that match their children gainst their will,
Teach them not how to live, but how to kill.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Parrot, Parrot,
Ile stop your prating, breake into her chamber,
And lay the villaine bleeding at her feete.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Villaine? it is my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Enter and kill him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: Enter, but kill him he that dares, I blush
To see two Princes so degenerate

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Oh noble brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: What would you have him doe?
He well deserves to have her to his wife;
Who gives to you a daughter, her a life,
In sight of angels she to him was given,
So that in striking him, you fight with heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: You see there is no remedie.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: Troth none;
I threw at all (and gamesters lucke) all's gone;
Farewell brave spirited girle, he that gainst winde,
Fier and the sea, law and a womans minde,
Strives, is a foole, that's I, Ile now be wise,
And neuer more put trust in womans eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: I love thee for that word with-all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Will you come downe pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Sweare as you are a Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Yet more a doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: Will you not trust your father?

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Why should I? you see there is no trust i'th'daughter;
Sweare by your hopes of good you will not touch
His naile to hurt him.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: By my hopes I sweare.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: And you too?

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: Yes, what's falling none can reare.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Wee come then noble friend, flagg not thy wings,
In this warr I defie a campe of Kings.
SP.STAGE: Enter Nicolletto, Tibaldo, Alphonsin. Daariene, Alissand, Trebatio.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: See, see, more shoales of friends, most beauteous Ladies,
Faire welcomes to you all.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: My Lord those tides,
Are turn'd, these Ladies are transform'd to brides.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: We heard the happy newes, and therefore sent,
To marry joyes with joyes, yours, with our owne,
Yours (I see) prosper, ours are overthrowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: How meane you overthrowne?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Your owne eyes shall be witnesse how: nay, nay, pray rise,
I know your heart is up, tho your knees downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.L: All that we stand in feare of is your frowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: And all deare father which I begge of you,
Is that you love this man but as I doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: What begg you of this Prince?

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: That he would take
One favour from me, which my selfe shall make.

SP.SPEAKER: Pisa.
SP.L: Pray let it be of willow.

SP.SPEAKER: Fia.
SP.L: Well then it shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: Why willow? is the noble Prince forsaken?

SP.SPEAKER: Pier.
SP.L: All womens faults, one for another taken,

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Now in good sooth my Lord, shee has but vs'd you
As watermen use their fares, for shee look'd one way,
And row'd another, you but wore her glove,
The hand was Angeloes, and she dealt wisely.
Let woman ne're love man, or if she doe,
Let him nere know it, make him write, waite woe,
Court, cogge, and curse, and sweare, and lie, and pine,
Till Love bring him to death's doore, else hee's not mine,
That flesh eates sweetest that's pick'd close to th' bone,
Water drinkes best, that's hew'd euen from the stone;
Men must be put to 't home.

SP.SPEAKER: Nico.
SP.L: He that loves ducking, let him come learne of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Shee has good skill;
At table will wee heare a full discourse
Of all these changes, and these Marriages,
Both how they shuffled, cut, and dealt about,
What cards are best, after the trumpes were out,
Who plaid false play, who true, who sought to save
An Ace ith'bottome, and turn'd up a knave;
For Love is but a Card-play, and all's lost,
Vnlesse you cogg, hee that pack's best, wins must,

SP.SPEAKER: Alp.
SP.L: Since such good gamsters are together met,
As you like this, wee'le play another sett.
